facts.claim: Open interest (rather than options volume) is the best tool for analyzing option activity. It is a much more stable number
facts.context: Comparison of open interest vs volume for technical analysis

facts.claim: Heavy put open interest at or below current price levels creates structural support through delta hedging by put sellers who buy underlying stocks
facts.context: How put OI creates support levels

facts.claim: Strikes at which there is heavy out-of-the-money call open interest potentially represent resistance
As stocks approach out-of-the-money strikes, delta increases, forcing sellers to hedge by purchasing underlying shares (for puts) or shorting stock (for calls)
Strikes of heavy open interest do not always act as precise resistance/support levels
facts.context: Limitation and caveat about OI reliability

facts.claim: Volume can be misleading because it reflects transient day-trading activity and position closures, whereas open interest reveals true trader positioning at day's end
facts.context: Why OI is superior to volume

facts.claim: Round-number strikes amplify psychological significance of support/resistance levels

summary: Schaeffer's Research emphasizes that open interest is superior to volume for technical analysis due to its stability. Heavy put OI creates support through delta hedging mechanisms, while heavy call OI represents resistance. However, these levels are not always precise and depend on delta values and hedging activity.

key_metrics.oi_concentration_thresholds: Not specified - described as 'heavy' without numerical values
key_metrics.reliability_factors: Delta values, hedging status, round-number strikes

source.title: Max Pain (Options) - Overview, How It Works, Calculation
source.author: CFI Team

facts.claim: Max pain is a situation in which the stock price locks in on an option strike price as it nears expiration, which would cause financial losses

facts.claim: Open Interest (OI) represents the total number of outstanding option contracts that have not been settled or closed
Volume is the number of contracts traded in a session, while Open Interest is the total number of active positions
Price up + OI up = Long buildup (Bullish signal, new longs entering)
Price down + OI up = Short buildup (Bearish signal, new shorts entering)
Price up + OI down = Short covering (Bullish but potentially temporary)
Price down + OI down = Long unwinding (Bearish but potentially temporary)
Highest Call OI = Resistance Level: Price tends to get rejected near high call open interest levels
Highest Put OI = Support Level: Price often bounces from high put open interest levels
Rising volume combined with rising open interest confirms trend strength and indicates new participants are entering with conviction
Open interest alone doesn't provide clear buy or sell signals, but it adds valuable context when combined with price action and volume analysis

summary: Comprehensive guide explaining open interest as total outstanding contracts. Provides clear four-quadrant framework for interpreting price/OI relationships: long buildup, short buildup, short covering, and long unwinding. Emphasizes that highest call OI marks resistance while highest put OI marks support.

key_metrics.support_resistance: Highest OI concentrations mark key levels

facts.claim: Put/Call Ratio = Put Volume / Call Volume
Values above 1.0 indicate more put volume (bearish positioning), while values below 1.0 suggest call dominance (bullish positioning)
Upper extreme: 1.20+ signals excessive bearishness
facts.context: Put/Call ratio threshold for bearish extremes

facts.claim: Lower extreme: 0.70 or below indicates excessive bullishness
facts.context: Put/Call ratio threshold for bullish extremes

facts.claim: For smoothed 10-day SMA: Bearish threshold at 0.95; bullish threshold at 0.80
Index Put/Call ($CPCI) 200-day MA: 1.41
Equity Put/Call ($CPCE) 200-day MA: 0.61
Total Put/Call ($CPC) 200-day MA: 0.91

A Put/Call Ratio at its lower extremities would show excessive bullishness because call volume would be significantly higher than put volume. In contrarian terms, excessive bullishness would argue for caution and the possibility of a stock market decline
A bullish signal occurs when the indicator moves above the bearish extreme (.95) and then back below. A bearish signal occurs when the indicator moves below the bullish extreme (.80) and back above
Equity ($CPCE) reflects retail trader sentiment and stays below 1.0 (call-biased), while Index ($CPCI) represents professional traders and consistently stays above 1.0 due to hedging
Professional traders use index puts for downside protection, while retail participants favor calls for directional bullish bets

summary: Comprehensive guide to put/call ratio as a contrarian sentiment indicator. Provides specific numerical thresholds: 1.20+ for bearish extremes, 0.70 for bullish extremes. Distinguishes between equity (retail, call-biased), index (professional, put-biased), and total ratios. Emphasizes combining with other technical tools for confirmation.

source.title: Open Interest: Overview, Calculation, Analysis, Trading Guide, Tool
source.author: Strike.money
